title: West Cambridge
caption: Weld Boathouse sits along the Charles census tract with the highest life expectancy in the state at 91.8 years.<sup>7</sup> Nestled between Harvard University and Mount Auburn Cemetery, this census tract has a median household income over $200,000.<sup>8</sup>
Entrance to Havrard's multimillion dollar state-of-the-art athletic facilities.

title: A Tale of Two Allstons
caption: Stepping off Harvard property in Allston brings wealth disparities into sharp relief. In the area directly abutting HBS, the median household income is more than $150,000,<sup>9</sup> while just a few stops down the bus line that drops below $50,000 <sup>10</sup> and directly off the bus line it is $33,000, barely above the federal poverty line.<sup>11</sup>

title: The Boston Expansion that Never Was
caption: Brookline has long been one of the richest parts of Massachusetts. The neighboring towns of West Roxbury and Brighton joined the growing city of Boston in the late 19th century, but Brookline refused to join because it wanted to avoid high-density housing zoning and paying taxes to subsidize a much larger and poorer neighbor.<sup>12</sup>
One of the few Blue Ribbon schools in the state.

title: The Paradox of Proximity
caption: Longwood Medical Area is home to Harvard Medical School, the Harvard Chan School of Public Health, and some of most advanced hospitals in the world: Brigham and Women's, Boston Children's, Dana-Farber, and Beth Israel. Longwood is also a major driver of medical research, containing four of the nation's five largest recipients of NIH research funding.<sup>13</sup>
Countway Library of Medicine at Harvard Medical School
Brighman and Women's (left), Boston Children's (center), Beth Israel (not pictured, behind Boston Children's)

title: Wealth and Health
caption: In the  census tract that includes Harvard Medical School, nearly 40% of residents live below the poverty line, and many lack access to basic healthcare.<sup>14</sup>

title: So close yet so far
caption: A staggering 95% of children — and more than half of all residents — live below the poverty line in the census tract that includes Roxbury’s Nubian Station, the terminus of Route 66. Median household income is barely above $20,000, a tenth of what it is in West Cambridge.<sup>15</sup> Nubian Square has the lowest life expectancy in Boston, at only 69 years old, and one of the highest rates of preventable deaths in the city, at 283 per 100,000 — more than double the rate of Back Bay and other affluent areas such as Cambridge.<sup>6</sup> This is despite the fact that it is within a mile of five Level One Trauma Centers — three in Longwood, as well as Tufts Medical Center and BU's Boston Medical Center.

title: Methadone Mile
caption: This area between Nubian Station and the intersection of Mass. and Cass is known as Methadone Mile. The epicenter of the opioid and homelessness epidemics in Eastern Massachusetts. The city moved hundreds of homeless people to this area after the closing of shelters on Long Island in Boston Harbor, creating a tent city.<sup>16</sup>
